text: I feel like there was a time (mid-2000s?), when there was an effort to help make progressive outlets strong. Feels like that’s not the case as much anymore. More often folks — including progressives — just go to traditional outlets with scoops, etc.
author: aterkel

text: And we’re going back to a worse time, when local/state newspapers aren’t nearly as strong. I love the NYT and WaPo as much as the next person, but they shouldn't be the only thriving outlets.
author: aterkel

text: I remember when I got into media in 2005, nontraditional sources (blogs, etc) were starting to thrive. It was really really good. It’s very depressing to see so many of those nontraditional outlets now downsizing (and those journalists losing their jobs).

text: As we wait for the FBI report, I wrote a piece about how the GOP used the FBI investigation in 1991 to discredit Anita Hill
author: aterkel

text: The FBI agents also remembered Hill saying something. But Hill said she had clearly said something else. That was also used to discredit her, as if she was dissembling.
author: aterkel

text: Hill talked to the FBI before her testimony. She gave far more detail in her testimony about what Thomas did. That made the FBI look like they had done a sloppy job interviewing her. So they decided to throw her under the bus and suggest that she was embellishing her story now.
author: aterkel

text: People are pinning a lot of their hopes on the FBI investigation into Kavanaugh. But it might not have the outcome you expect: In 1991, Anita Hill's FBI interview ended up being used against her by the GOP. http://bit.ly/2E2BJGG

text: The flag stuff yesterday really was ridiculous, and it created confusion and ridiculousness around the country for federal workers
author: aterkel

text: What? The office temp here is definitely more Cuomo. And I’m saying that as someone who thinks 76 is too hot.

text: The federal workers I talked to said they couldn’t remember anything like this happening. Usually, flag lowering is standard. You are told a start and end date. That’s it. Nothing like the drama yesterday.
author: aterkel

text: A USDA employee who sent out the order to lower the flag, and then sent out the cancellation notice, got such backlash from employees that she had to email again to clarify it wasn’t her making the decision.
author: aterkel

text: One postal worker told me it was really embarrassing for them: "In small towns when you lower the flag people want to know why and use it as a signal to lower their own. It put us all in a bad position to explain why we would be putting our flags back up"
author: aterkel

text: Trump’s flag drama created serious confusion across the fed gov’t. Places like post offices, national parks got 3 emails yesterday: Lower the flag, don’t lower the flag, okay lower the flag. http://bit.ly/2LzBb9N
author: aterkel

text: Looking for other federal employees who got emails yesterday with guidance about whether to raise/lower the flag. Drop me a DM or email me. Thanks!
author: aterkel

text: Employee says the flag lowering process is usually very straightforward — start and end time. This was... different.
author: aterkel

text: National Park Service employee tells me they got an email around 10am ordering flags at half staff. Around 2:30pm, email went out cancelling it and saying flag should go back to regular order. And around 5:30, another one went out saying to lower again.
